timeline.message:
Include transitive dependencies in Cargo.toml.

The new structure of generated Rust code precisely follows the DDlog
project structure, meaning that each Rust module only needs to import
modules imported by the corresponding DDlog module and hence each Rust
crate must import crates containing at least on dependency of a module
from this crate.

Turns out theere is one exception to this rule: the type inference
engine adds type annotations to generic functions, which may refer to
types defined in modules not directly imported by the current module.
To handle such cases without a more elaborate dependency analysis, we
simply add a transitive closure of dependencies, not just direct
dependencies, to each crate.  I don't think this will affect compilation
time, including incremental compilation, significantly.

+-- | Update an entire directory tree, updating files whose contents has changed,
+-- creating new files and deleting files not in `files` list, but keeping
+-- files that haven't changed unmodified.
+updateDirectory :: FilePath -> M.Map FilePath String -> IO ()
+updateDirectory dir files = do
+    -- Prepend directory path to all file names.
+    let files' = M.mapKeys (dir </>) files
+    -- Current directory contents.
+    existing_files <- traverseDir dir
+    -- Files not in the tree.
+    let to_delete = filter (\f -> M.notMember f files') existing_files
+    mapM_ removeFile to_delete
+    -- Update or create files in the tree.
+    mapM_ (\(mpath, mtext) -> updateFile mpath mtext)
+          $ M.toList files'
+
+-- | Traverse directory tree, returning the list of files in it.
+traverseDir :: FilePath -> IO [FilePath]

timeline.message:
Remove old files from `types/`.

When creating the Rust project, the compiler only overwrites files that
have changed, leaving other files unmodified.  It also did not remove
old files, which caused compilation errors in some cases.  This became
more common with the new crate decomposition algorithm that can generate
a completely different Rust project structure as DDlog module
dependencies change.  This patch removes old files from the `type`
directory.  This prevents problems in most cases, as only files in `types`
change across compiler runs.

In the future we should do the same for the entire generated project, as
files outside of `types` can change across different ddlog versions,
causing compilation errors on upgrade.  This will require a bit more
refactoring to make sure that we first build a complete project tree in
memory before overwriting it on the disk.
